snippet: While there is near-universal agreement that the 14-year-old No Child Left Behind law should be retooled, the paths to change are starkly different.
abstract: Both houses of Congress have begun efforts to overhaul No Child Left Behind education law, focusing on much-criticized high-stakes testing and punishments doled out to schools that do not measure up; proposed means of altering federal involvement in schools differ greatly, with House passing partisan bill opposed by Democrats and Senate seeking middle ground.

byline.original: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER and MOTOKO RICH
byline.contributor: Jennifer Steinhauer reported from Washington, and Motoko Rich from New York.

lead_paragraph: While there is near-universal agreement that the 14-year-old No Child Left Behind law should be retooled, the paths to change are starkly different.

headline.main: Lawmakers Move to Limit Government’s Role in Education
headline.print_headline: Lawmakers Seek to Cut Federal Role in Schools
